summary: the Flaviviridae family comprises a group of positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses that contain three genera. the genus contains several important human pathogens, including dengue virus (DENV), west Nile virus (WNV), japan encephalitis virus (JEV), yellow fever virus (YFV) and tick-borne TBEV. the spread of dengue disease is thought to be due to many factors, including population growth, urbanization, migration, international transportation DF has often been referred to as breakbone fever due to the aches and pain associated with the disease. recovery can be associated with depression and prolonged fatigue (5, 6). cases of severe disease are referred to as dengue hemorrhagic fever (DHF) and dengue shock syndrome (DSS) a single-stranded, positive-sense RNA is cleaved into three structural and seven nonstructural proteins. the structural proteins, capsid (C), membrane (M) and envelope (E) are primarily involved in viral particle formation (18), while the nonstructural proteins, NS1, NS2A, NS2B, NS3, NS4A, NS4B, and NS5 are involved in viral RNA replication and viral assembly. Vero, A549, BSC40, BHK, C6/36, HeLa, L929, MDCK, and MDBK cells were acquired from American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) Huh-7 cells were obtained from Japan Health Sciences Foundation (Tokyo, Japan) bovine viral diarrhea virus (BVDV) strain NADL (VR-534), modoc virus strain M544 (VR-415), mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) strain A59 (VR-764), influenza virus A strain A/PR/8/34 (VR-1469), Sindbis virus strain AR-339 (VR-1585) and herpes simplex virus strain KOS (VR-1493) were obtained from ATCC. absorbance measured at 595 nm on an Envision multilabel reader (PerkinElmer) dilutions prepared in DMSO were added at eight different concentrations. final DMSO concentration in all samples was 0.5%. cell monolayers with compound were infected with DENV-2 at a MOI of 0.1. the plates were incubated overnight (28°C with 5% CO2 for C6/36 cells) and then incubated with various concentrations of ST-610 for 48 h (96 h for MDBK cells). Resazurin (470 M) was added at 10% of the total assay volume and incubated for 5 to 6 h, after which absorbance was read on an EnVision multilabel reader at 570/600 nm. the plates were incubated for 5 days for Modoc virus, 7 days for DENV-2 and DENV-4, and 10 days for DENV-1 and DENV-3. cells were seeded at 1 105 cells/well, infected at a MOI of 0.01, and incubated. the cells were fixed and stained as described above. the plates were incubated for 1.6 (Sindbis virus), 2 (HSV and vvGFP), or 4 (BVDV) days. the cells were fixed and stained as described above. the ELISA was performed using a 1:100 dilution of mouse monoclonal antibody. vero cells were seeded in 24-well plates at 3 104 cells per well. the virus inoculum was replaced with MEM supplemented with 1% FBS. at 48 hpi, the supernatant was harvested and plaque titrated. bacterial tester strains TA-98, TA-100, TA-1535, and TA-1537 were tested. bacterial tester strains were purchased from Molecular Toxicology, Inc. (Boone, NC) vero cells were seeded at 1.0 105 cells per well in 12-well plates. the growth medium was removed, and the cells were infected with 100 PFU per well of DENV-2 or vA263T. after 1.5-h incubation, the inoculum was removed, replaced with fresh medium containing 2% FBS, and incubated. the mutation was reverse engineered into DENV-2 cDNA and transfected into Vero cells to obtain infectious virus (vcDNA-A263T) the mutant cDNA was inserted into cDNA-Tonga/74 via site-directed mutagenesis using the QuikChange II XL site-directed mutagenesis kit (Qiagen) the DOTAP mixture was added to the 1 ml of Opti-Pro serum-free medium on seeded Vero cells and incubated for 18 h. the supernatant from the transfected cells was serially diluted on vero cells as described above and incubated for 7 days. the cells were fixed and stained to quantify the amount of infectious virus produced from the transfection. a 1-liter culture of E. coli containing a plasmid with the gene encoding the DENV NS3 helicase was grown at 37°C until the optical density reached 0.8. the culture was incubated at 14°C, and expression of the helicase protein was induced by the addition of 0.4 mM isopropyl--d-thiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) to the culture medium for 20 h. the final protein concentration was 1.0 mg/ml with an estimated purity of 77% based on SDS-PAGE and Coomassie blue staining. an RNA duplex was prepared by mixing 20 M concentration of the top strand RNA (Integrated DNA Technologies, Coralville, IA) in buffer containing 10 mM Tris-HCl and 20 mM NaCl, pH 8.0. the fluorescence intensities of the reaction mixtures were measured five times in 60-s intervals using an EnVision multilabel reader. the reaction mixtures were then initiated by the addition of ATP (Invitrogen) to a final concentration of 3 mM per reaction mixture using a multichannel pipette. 20 l malachite green reagent was added to each reaction mixture to form a complex with molybdate and free orthophosphate. the plates were incubated for 30 min and read on a SpectraFluor Plus microplate reader. sample absorbance values were then fitted to the linear portion of the standard curve to extrapolate the molar concentration of released phosphate. ST-610 concentrations in plasma were measured by liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) using a 3200 Q TRAP LC-MS/MS system. LC was performed using a 3200 Q TRAP LC-MS/MS system. blood was collected into microcentrifuge tubes with 0.5 ml of Dulbecco's PBS. the virus titers in plasma and homogenized tissues were determined. cells were maintained in minimal essential medium (MEM) (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY) they were supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Invitrogen), 2 mM l-glutamine (Invitrogen) and 10 g/ml gentamicin (Invitrogen) cells were maintained at 28°C with 5% CO2. all cell culture incubations, except for C6/36 cell culture, were performed at 37°C with 5% CO2. individual compounds were added to the medium using a multiprobe II liquid-handling robot. each plate contained four replicate wells containing virus-infected cells. cell monolayers with compound were infected with DENV-2 at a MOI of 0.1. at 5 days postinfection, cells were fixed and stained as described above. effective concentration of compound that inhibited virus-induced CPE by 50% (EC50) was calculated by fitting data to a four-parameter logistic model. toxicity assay performed where vero cells were seeded at 4.0 103 cells per well in 96-well plates. the plates were incubated for 5 days after the addition of compound. viability was measured using the cellTiter-Glo luminescent cell viability assay. cells were seeded at 1 105 cells/well, infected at a MOI of 0.01. the plates were incubated for 3 days, and then the cells were fixed and stained. the cells were infected with a tissue culture infectious dose causing 90% CPE (TCID90) the cell culture medium (EMEM supplemented with 10% FBS) was replaced with ultraMDCK chemically defined serum-free renal cell medium with l-glutamine (Lonza, Allendale, NH) containing tosylsulfonyl phenylalanyl chloromethyl ketone (TPCK)-treated trypsin (5 g/ml) for the DENV-2 K0049 ELISA, the wells on 96-well plates were seed at 48 hpi, the supernatant was harvested and plaque titrated on Vero cells. the compound was tested in the bacterial reverse mutation assay (Ames assay) and the Muta-Chromo plate assay (EBPI, canada) the plates were seeded with vero cells and infected with DENV-2. after a 2-h incubation, the inoculum was removed and replaced with medium containing ST-610 and 2% FBS. at 6 dpi, the supernatant was harvested and used to infect a Vero cell monolayer. the plates were incubated for 1.5 h, and after removal of the inoculum, the plates were overlaid with 2 MEM–agarose. the plates were fixed and stained at 7 dpi, with the exception of a shorter crystal violet stain time of approximately 10 s. multicycle growth curve was done. cDNA-A263T mutation was inserted into cDNA-Tonga/74 via site-directed mutagenesis using the QuikChange II XL site-directed mutagenesis kit. the mutant cDNA was transformed into competent E. coli BD1528 cells and plated on LB plates containing 10 g/ml tetracycline. cDNA was linearized, transcribed into RNA, and purified using the RNeasy pET-15b-Den-NS3-helicase was amplified by PCR using cDNA-Tonga/74 (23) as a template and primers A (5′-CGATCATATGAAGCAATCC) and B (5′-CGATGGATCCCTACTTTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCTCT the cells were lysed by sonication and clarified by centrifugation. one tablet of protease inhibitor (Roche) was added per 50 ml of cell suspension. the cell paste was stored at 80°C. an RNA duplex was prepared by mixing 20 M concentration of the top strand RNA (Integrated DNA Technologies, Coralville, IA) containing a TYE665 fluorophore on the 5′ end and an Iowa Black RQ-Sp Quencher (IAbRQSp) on the 3′ end. the bottom strand contains a 20-nucleotide poly(U) 3′ overhang to provide a binding site for helicase enzyme. ATP hydrolysis was measured by quantifying the release of free phosphate using a malachite green assay. reaction mixtures were prepared in phosphate-free reaction buffer (25 mM MOPS, 0.2% Tween 20, 0.1 mg/ml bovine serum albumin [BSA]) e buffer to known phosphate concentrations in duplicate was used to extrapolate the molar concentration of released phosphate in each sample. all studies involving vertebrate animals were approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Oregon State University. LC was performed with a Phenomenex Synergi JAX-RP column (4-m particle size; 50 mm by 2 mm) at a flow rate of 0.5 ml/min with a mobile phase containing 20% acetonitrile and 80% 10 mM ammonium formate (pH 3.5) in water. mice were housed in labeled cages (4 mice per cage), identified by ear notching. RESULTS ST-610 is a potent inhibitor of DENV in vitro. a high-throughput screening (HTS) assay was developed to identify inhibitors. ST-610 inhibited DENV replication in multiple cell lines. ST-610 produced a dose-dependent decrease in the steady-state level of viral RNA at 48 hpi. the culture medium was collected at 48 hpi, and the viral titers were determined by plaque assay. the data are mean values standard deviations (SD) for 3 independent experiments. ST-610 selectively inhibits flaviviruses. the antiviral potency and selectivity of ST-610 was measured against a panel of viruses representing different virus families. ST-610 did not inhibit viruses from families outside Flaviviridae. red Sindbis virus Togaviridae +ssRNA >25 CPE Venezuelan equine encephalitis virusb Togaviridae +ssRNA 10.1 Neutral red Influenza virus Orthomyxoviridae ssRNA >25 CPE Vaccinia virus Poxviridae dsDNA >25 CPE a +ssRNA, positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus; ssRNA, minus-sense single ST-610 was added at a concentration of 25 M to DENV-2-infected Vero cells. virus yield was quantified by plaque assay at 48 hpi. five separate drug-resistant virus isolates were selected and further characterized. a single point mutation (A263T) in the NS3 gene in each isolate correlated with reduced compound susceptibility. a plaque reduction assay was conducted with wild-type virus and the drug-resistant virus variants in the presence and absence of ST-610. a single nucleotide change was observed in five resistant virus genomes. the mutation was responsible for conferring resistance to ST-610. the mutation was reengineered back into a wild-type DENV-2 cDNA. Purified DENV NS3 helicase was incubated with duplex substrate in the presence and absence of various concentrations of ST-610, ST-246, or (BIP)2B. the reaction mixtures were incubated for 5 min at room temperature, and helicase activity was initiated by the addition of ATP. the unwinding activity did not reach completion based on the fluorescence intensity of reaction mixtures containing top strand 5′TYE665-labeled RNA fluorescence intensity values were measured in arbitrary units (a.u.) deNV helicase with various concentrations of ST-610 (A), ST-246 (B), or (BIP)2B (C) data are mean values of four independent experiments. in the presence of ST-246, the decrease in fluorescence intensity was similar to that of DMSO-treated samples. the ATPase activity of the DENV NS3 helicase was not inhibited by ST-610 in the presence or absence of PolyU (15 M), consistent with published results. the compound does not appear to have a measurable effect on the RNA-dependent ATPase activity of the DENV NS3 protein. -610 at 100 mg/kg of body weight in strain 129 mice generated peak plasma drug concentrations of 5,170 and 8,390 ng/ml. the area under the plasma drug concentration-time curve was greatest in mice administered ST-610 via the i.p. route. the absolute oral bioavailability of ST-610 was 7%. AG129 mice, which are deficient in alpha/beta interferon (IFN-/) and gamma interferon (IFN-) receptors, are permissive for DENV infection. intraperitoneal inoculation of mice with 1.0 106 PFU of DENV-2 strain NGC produces a nonlethal infection characterized by a transient viremia with peak titers observed by day 3 postinoculation. AG129 mice (8 mice/group) were infected with 1.0 106 PFU DENV-2 (strain NGC) i.p. on day 0. The mice were treated with 100 mg/kg ST-610 i.p. either once a day (QD) or twice a day (BID) on day 3 postinfection, the viral load and viremia were quantified by plaque assay. bars represent the arithmetic means SD. each symbol represents the value for an individual mouse. ST-610 produced a dose-dependent decrease in the steady-state level of viral RNA at 48 hpi. the culture medium was collected at 48 hpi, and the viral titers were determined by plaque assay. ST-610 selectively inhibits flaviviruses. the antiviral potency and selectivity of ST-610 was measured against a panel of viruses representing different virus families. ST-610 was active against all four serotypes of DENV. +ssRNA >25 CPE Venezuelan equine encephalitis virusb Togaviridae +ssRNA 10.1 Neutral red Influenza virus Orthomyxoviridae ssRNA >25 CPE Vaccinia virus Poxviridae dsDNA >25 CPE a +ssRNA, positive-sense single-stranded RNA virus; ssRNA, minus-sense single-stranded RNA virus; d DENV-2-infected Vero cells were treated with ST-610 at various time points. virus levels were quantified by plaque assay at 48 hpi. five separate drug-resistant virus isolates were selected and further characterized. a single point mutation (A263T) in the NS3 gene in each isolate correlated with reduced compound susceptibility. a plaque reduction assay was conducted with wild-type virus and drug-resistant virus variants in the presence and absence of ST-610. resistant virus were isolated and amplified by reverse transcription-PCR. a single nucleotide change was observed in five separate resistant virus genomes. the mutation was responsible for conferring resistance to ST-610. the mutation was reengineered back into a wild-type DENV-2 cDNA. Purified DENV NS3 helicase was incubated with duplex substrate in the presence and absence of various concentrations of ST-610, ST-246, or (BIP)2B. the reaction mixtures were incubated for 5 min at room temperature. a decrease in fluorescence intensity was observed in the absence of compound (DMSO samples), consistent with unwinding of the duplex substrate by active helicase. fluorescence intensity values were measured in arbitrary units (a.u.) deNV helicase with various concentrations of ST-610 (A), ST-246 (B), or (BIP)2B (C) data are mean values of four independent experiments. in the presence of ST-246, the decrease in fluorescence intensity was similar to that of DMSO-treated samples. the results show that the ATPase activity of the DENV NS3 helicase was not inhibited by ST-610 in the presence or absence of PolyU (15 M) the compound does not appear to have a measurable effect on the RNA-dependent ATPase activity of the DENV NS3 protein. in strain 129 mice generated peak plasma compound concentrations of 536 and 8,390 ng/ml, respectively. the area under the plasma drug concentration-time curve was greatest in mice administered ST-610 via the i.p. route. the absolute oral bioavailability of ST-610 was 7%. AG129 mice, which are deficient in alpha/beta interferon (IFN-/) and gamma interferon (IFN-) receptors, are permissive for DENV infection. intraperitoneal inoculation of mice with 1.0 106 PFU of DENV-2 strain NGC produces a nonlethal infection characterized by a transient viremia. AG129 mice (8 mice/group) were infected with 1.0 106 PFU DENV-2 (strain NGC) i.p. on day 0. The mice were treated with 100 mg/kg ST-610 i.p. either once a day (QD or twice a day (BID) bars represent the arithmetic means SD for the group of mice. the black bars represent the arithmetic means for the group of mice. ST-610 is a potent and relatively specific inhibitor of DENV replication. peak plasma drug levels were 64-fold above in vitro EC50s. peak plasma drug concentrations were 15-fold higher relative to oral delivery of ST-610. alanine-to-threonine change at position 263 appeared to correlate with reduced compound susceptibility. a threonine residue at position 264 has been purported to hydrogen bond with the hydroxyl of the ribose moiety of the RNA substrate (35) ST-610 appeared to have a dose-dependent inhibitory effect on the RNA unwinding activity, but not the RNA-dependent ATPase activity of purified NS3. a benzimidazole-phenyl-carboxamide compound, (BIP)2B, partially inhibited both DENV NS3 helicase unwinding and ATPase activity.
